Itote rose to become one of the Mau Mau's most influential commanders. He was captured in 1954 and sentenced to life imprisonment. However, he was released in 1959 as part of a general amnesty. 

After Kenya's independence in 1963, Itote served in the new government as a member of parliament and as an assistant minister. prompt: Tell me a bio of Lees Knowles

Knowles was elected to the House of Commons in 1892 as a Liberal Member of Parliament for the Strand division of London. He was a strong supporter of free trade and Irish Home Rule. In 1895, he was appointed Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, a position he held until 1900.

In addition to his political career, Knowles was a prolific writer. He wrote several books on history and politics, including "The Statesman's Year-Book" and "The Union and Its Adversaries". He was also a regular contributor to the "Edinburgh Review" and the "Nineteenth Century".

Knowles died on March 28, 1928, in London. He is remembered for his contributions to British politics and literature.

prompt: Tell me a bio of Frederick Howard Taylor
name: Frederick Howard Taylor
response:
Frederick Winslow Taylor (March 20, 1856 – March 21, 1915) was an American mechanical engineer who sought to improve industrial efficiency. He was one of the first management consultants and is widely regarded as the father of scientific management, a management theory which would become known as Taylorism.

Taylor's most significant contribution to the field of management was his development of a series of principles for scientific management. These principles included the idea that work should be scientifically studied and standardized, that workers should be selected, trained, and paid based on their ability to perform specific tasks, and that there should be a clear division of labor between managers and workers.

Taylor's ideas were controversial at the time, and they remain so today. Critics argue that his approach was overly rigid and dehumanizing, and that it failed to take into account the importance of worker motivation and job satisfaction. Nevertheless, Taylor's work had a profound impact on the development of modern management theory, and his ideas continue to be studied and debated in business schools and corporations around the world.
